newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: FOCUS-C-C Amatil finalises San Miguel deal.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-C-C Amatil finalises San Miguel deal.

text.p: Shareholders in Australian soft-drink bottler Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd gave final approval on Tuesday to an agreement with San Miguel Corp to create the largest Coca-Cola bottler outside the United States.

"With good sales margins and relatively high per capita consumption the Philippines offers C-C Amatil shareholders substantial and immediate bottom-line benefits," chairman Dean Wills told an extraordinary general meeting.
Under the share-swap deal, C-C Amatil will acquire the giant Philippine group's soft-drink subsidiary, while San Miguel will receive 192.5 million shares, a 25 percent stake, in C-C Amatil.

The Coca-Cola Co, which owned 30 percent of the San Miguel subsidiary, Coca-Cola Bottler Philippines Inc (CCBPI), will also be issued with new shares in C-C Amatil, but its total holding will be diluted to 33 percent from 36 percent.
The deal was valued at A$3.4 billion, based on C-C Amatil's average share price in March, but is worth considerably more at present.

While some San Miguel shareholders felt they should have received a greater stake in C-C Amatil, the merger has kickstarted the Australian group's shares off their lows following a profit warning late last year.
Since the April 3 announcement, C-C Amatil's share price has soared to past the A$17 mark from below A$12, a 43 percent gain in just three months.
Analysts have said C-C Amatil would receive an immediate boost from the acquisition, given that CCBPI generated almost identical profits to C-C Amatil in 1996, but on half the sales.
Wills told reporters after the meeting he believed the share price rise was also driven by the market's assessment of the company's future potential.
Based on 1996 figures, the expanded group would service a consumer population of 450 milion people, generate sales revenue of A$4.87 billion and a net profit of about A$286 million.
"This is of great strategic importance to us," said Wills. (It) gives us a very strong foundation in Asia."
Analysts have speculated that C-C Amatil may continue its rapid expansion, seeking franchises in other Asian countries, in particular the vast Indian market.
Wills said C-C Amatil was aiming to increase total consumption in its Asian markets, and would look to replicate the success of marketing in the Philippines in other Asia countries.
Some cost savings could also be expected through strategies such as combining sugar purchases, although the CCBPI was very well run.
"Our number one objective (in the Philippines) is to keep that management team in place," added chief executive Norb Cole.

San Miguel will take four places on an expanded C-C Amatil board as part of the deal, and has nominated its chairman and chief executive Andres Soriano and chief finance officer-treasurer Delfin Gonzalez.

Rafael Alunan, a former secretary of the department of the interior and local government, is the third nominee, while a fourth, independent director -- who will also be an Austraian citizen -- has yet to be named.
C-C Amatil shares were trading 22 cents lower at A$16.98 at 3.55 p.m. (0540 GMT).
